document.title: Existence of stochastic entropy solutions for stochastic scalar balance laws with Lipschitz vector fieldsThis work was partially supported by NNSF of China (Grant No. 11171122)

creator.personname: Jinlong Wei1, Liang Ding2, Bin Liu3 1School of Statistics and Mathematics, Zhongnan University of Economics and Law, Wuhan 430073, Hubei, P.R.China 2Department of Basis Education Dehong Vocational College Dehong, Yunnan, 678400, P.R.China 3School of Mathematics and Statistics, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, P.R.China

para.p: Abstract In this paper, we consider a scalar stochastic balance law and gain the existence for stochastic entropy solutions. Our proof relies on the BGK approximation and the generalized It√¥ formula. Moreover, as an application, we derive the existence of stochastic entropy solutions for stochastic Buckley-Leverett type equations. Keywords: Existence; Stochastic entropy solution; BGK approximation; It√¥ formula MSC (2010): 35L65; 60H15; 60H30
In this paper, we study the first-order scalar balance law with Stratonovich type perturbations:

para.p: it has been studied by many other researchers [3-5]. For example, in [3], Chen, Ding and Karlsen concern with (1.4),(1.1) with A‚Å¢(t,œÅ)=A‚Å¢(œÅ), then they supply an existence theory of stochastic entropy solutions for ùíû2 flux.

In above papers, existence of (stochastic) entropy solutions are proved via approximation by (stochastic) parabolic equations. Using a differential philosophy, Hofmanov√° in [6] proceeds a stochastic BGK approximation, and the existence of stochastic entropy solution is proved for ùíû4,Œ± (Œ±>0) flux and Lipschitz forcing.

All above mentioned works for stochastic balance laws are concentrated on ùíû2 (or ùíû4,Œ±) flux, there are relatively few research works for well-posedness of (1.1),(1.2) for ùíû1 flux. Our purpose now is to raise a well-posedness theory for L1‚à©L‚àû-solutions to (1.1).(1.2) on stochastic entropy solutions to the level of Kru≈ækov theory. Our present work is a fellow-up of Wei and Liu‚Äôs work [7]. In [7], the authors put forward the following result:

para.p: Then they derive the uniqueness of stochastic entropy solutions for (1.1),(1.2). Whence, to establish the well-posedness for (1.1),(1.2), it remains to found the existence of solutions, and it is the main interest of the paper here.
This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we review some notions. Section 3 is devoted to the existence on stochastic entropy solutions for (1.1),(1.2).

As usual, the notation used here is mostly standard. ùíü‚Å¢(‚Ñùd) is the space of all œÜ‚ààùíû‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñùd) with compact support. Correspondingly, ùíü+‚Å¢(‚Ñùd) represents the non-negative elements in ùíü‚Å¢(‚Ñùd). ‚Ñï denotes the set consisting of all natural numbers. W(t)=(W1(t),W2(t),‚ãØ,Wd(t))‚ä§ stands for the standard d-dimensional Wiener procss on the classical Wiener space (Œ©,‚Ñ±,P,(‚Ñ±t)t‚©æ0), i.e. Œ© is the space of all continuous functions from [0,‚àû) to ‚Ñùd with locally uniform convergence topology, ‚Ñ± is the Borel œÉ-field, P is the Wiener measure, (‚Ñ±t)t‚©æ0 is the natural filtration generated by the coordinate process Wt‚Å¢(œâ)=œât. The stochastic integration with a notation ‚àò is interpreted in Stratonovich sense and the others is It√¥‚Äôs. The C‚Å¢(T) denotes a positive constant depends only on T, whose values may change in different places. For a given measurable function f, f+ is its positive portion, defined by 1f‚©æ0‚Å¢f, and f-=[-f]+. The summation convention is enforced throughout this article, wherein summation is understood with respect to repeated indices.
In this short section, we introduce some notions and review the stochastic kinetic formula for future use.

Math.text: cases[[formulae@((d / (d * t)) * (open-interval@(X _ (list@(s, t)) * open-interval@(x, v), V _ (list@(s, t)) * v)) ^ top = (open-interval@(b * V _ (list@(s, t)), A * open-interval@(t, V _ (list@(s, t))))) ^ top, t >= s), ], [, ], [evaluated-at@((open-interval@(X _ (list@(s, t)) * open-interval@(x, v), V _ (list@(s, t)) * v)) ^ top, t = s) = (open-interval@(X * vector@(s, x, v), V * open-interval@(s, v))) ^ top, ]]

cases[[formulae@((d / (d * t)) * (open-interval@(X _ (list@(s, t)) * open-interval@(x, v), V _ (list@(s, t)) * v)) ^ top = (open-interval@(b * V _ (list@(s, t)), A * open-interval@(t, V _ (list@(s, t))))) ^ top, t >= s), ], [, ], [evaluated-at@((open-interval@(X _ (list@(s, t)) * open-interval@(x, v), V _ (list@(s, t)) * v)) ^ top, t = s) = (open-interval@(X * vector@(s, x, v), V * open-interval@(s, v))) ^ top, ]]

para.p: and (Xs,t‚Å¢(x,v),Vs,s‚Å¢(v))‚ä§=(X‚Å¢(t,X‚Å¢(s,x,v),V‚Å¢(s,v)),V‚Å¢(t,V‚Å¢(s,v)))‚ä§.
For any u‚ààLl‚Å¢o‚Å¢c‚àû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv))‚à©ùíû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L1‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv)), we define a mapping SŒµ by (3.5):

Math.text: S _ varepsilon * u * vector@(t, x, v) = (1 / varepsilon) * ((integral ^ t) _ 0)@(e ^ ((s - t) / varepsilon) * chi _ (rho ^ u * open-interval@(s, X _ (list@(t, s)) * open-interval@(x, v))) * V _ (list@(t, s)) * v * d * s) + e ^ (- t / varepsilon) * chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ u * X _ (list@(t, 0)) * open-interval@(x, v)) * V _ (list@(t, 0)) * v

S _ varepsilon * u * vector@(t, x, v) = (1 / varepsilon) * ((integral ^ t) _ 0)@(e ^ ((s - t) / varepsilon) * chi _ (rho ^ u * open-interval@(s, X _ (list@(t, s)) * open-interval@(x, v))) * V _ (list@(t, s)) * v * d * s) + e ^ (- t / varepsilon) * chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ u * X _ (list@(t, 0)) * open-interval@(x, v)) * V _ (list@(t, 0)) * v

para.p: here

Math.text: formulae@(rho ^ u * open-interval@(t, x) = (integral _ R)@(u * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v), (rho _ 0) ^ u * x = (integral _ R)@(u * vector@(0, x, v) * d * v) = rho _ 0 * x)

para.p: We claim that SŒµ is well-defined in Ll‚Å¢o‚Å¢c‚àû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv))‚à©ùíû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L1‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv)) and locally (in time) contractive in ùíû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L1‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv)).
Initially, we collate that (3.6) is well-defined. Indeed,

Math.text: (norm@(S _ varepsilon * u)) _ (L ^ infinity * closed-interval@(0, T) * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v) less= 1
(norm@(S _ varepsilon * u)) _ (L ^ infinity * closed-interval@(0, T) * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v) less= 1

para.p: and for any 0<T<‚àû,

Math.text: (supremum _ (0 less= t less= T))@(absolute-value@((1 / varepsilon) * ((integral ^ t) _ 0)@(e ^ ((s - t) / varepsilon) * d * s * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(chi _ (rho ^ u * open-interval@(s, X _ (list@(t, s)) * open-interval@(x, v))) * V _ (list@(t, s)) * v * d * x * d * v)) + e ^ (- t / varepsilon) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ u * X _ (list@(t, 0)) * open-interval@(x, v)) * V _ (list@(t, 0)) * v * d * x * d * v)))

(supremum _ (0 less= t less= T))@(absolute-value@((1 / varepsilon) * ((integral ^ t) _ 0)@(e ^ ((s - t) / varepsilon) * d * s * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(chi _ (rho ^ u * open-interval@(s, X _ (list@(t, s)) * open-interval@(x, v))) * V _ (list@(t, s)) * v * d * x * d * v)) + e ^ (- t / varepsilon) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ u * X _ (list@(t, 0)) * open-interval@(x, v)) * V _ (list@(t, 0)) * v * d * x * d * v)))

absent = (supremum _ (0 less= t less= T))@(absolute-value@((1 / varepsilon) * ((integral ^ t) _ 0)@(e ^ ((s - t) / varepsilon) * d * s * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(chi _ (rho ^ u * open-interval@(s, x)) * v * exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ s)@((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * open-interval@(r, V _ (list@(s, r)) * v) * d * r)) * d * x * d * v)) + e ^ (- t / varepsilon) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ u * x) * v * exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * open-interval@(r, V _ (list@(0, r)) * v) * d * r)) * d * x * d * v)))

absent less= exponential@(((integral ^ T) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * t * d * t)) * ((1 - e ^ (- T / varepsilon)) * (norm@(u)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)) + (norm@((rho _ 0) ^ u)) _ (L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))

exponential@(((integral ^ T) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * t * d * t)) * ((1 - e ^ (- T / varepsilon)) * (norm@(u)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)) + (norm@((rho _ 0) ^ u)) _ (L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))

para.p: thus (3.6) is meaningful.
For any f,g‚ààLl‚Å¢o‚Å¢c‚àû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv))‚à©ùíû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L1‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv)), an analogue calculation of (3.8) also leads to

Math.text: (norm@(S _ varepsilon * f - S _ varepsilon * g)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))
(norm@(S _ varepsilon * f - S _ varepsilon * g)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))

absent less= (supremum _ (0 less= t less= T))@(absolute-value@((1 / varepsilon) * ((integral ^ t) _ 0)@(e ^ ((s - t) / varepsilon) * d * s * integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))) * chi _ (rho ^ f * open-interval@(s, X _ (list@(t, s)) * open-interval@(x, v))) * V _ (list@(t, s)) * v) - chi _ (rho ^ g * open-interval@(s, X _ (list@(t, s)) * open-interval@(x, v))) * V _ (list@(t, s)) * v * absolute-value@(d * x * d * v + e ^ (- t / varepsilon) * integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)) * chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ f * X _ (list@(t, 0)) * open-interval@(x, v)) * V _ (list@(t, 0)) * v - chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ g * X _ (list@(t, 0)) * open-interval@(x, v)) * V _ (list@(t, 0)) * v * absolute-value@(d * x * d * v)

absent = (supremum _ (0 less= t less= T))@(absolute-value@((1 / varepsilon) * ((integral ^ t) _ 0)@(e ^ ((s - t) / varepsilon) * d * s * integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))) * chi _ (rho ^ f * open-interval@(s, x)) * v) - chi _ (rho ^ g * open-interval@(s, x)) * v * absolute-value@(exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ s)@((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * open-interval@(r, V _ (list@(s, r))) * d * r)) * d * x * d * v + e ^ (- t / varepsilon) * integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)) * chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ f * x) * v - chi _ ((rho _ 0) ^ g * x) * v * absolute-value@(exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * open-interval@(r, V _ (list@(0, r)) * v) * d * r)) * d * x * d * v)

absent less= exponential@(((integral ^ T) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * d * t)) * ((1 - e ^ (- T / varepsilon)) * (norm@(f - g)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)) + (norm@(f _ 0 - g _ 0)) _ (L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))

exponential@(((integral ^ T) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * d * t)) * ((1 - e ^ (- T / varepsilon)) * (norm@(f - g)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)) + (norm@(f _ 0 - g _ 0)) _ (L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))

para.p: In particular, if f0=g0=œáœÅ0, from (3.9),

Math.text: (norm@(S _ varepsilon * f - S _ varepsilon * g)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)) less= exponential@(((integral ^ T) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * t * d * t)) * (1 - e ^ (- T / varepsilon)) * (norm@(f - g)) _ (C * list@(closed-interval@(0, T), L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))

para.p: for any T>0.

Given above T>0 we select T1>0 so small that exp‚Å°(‚à´0T‚à•[‚àÇv‚Å°A]+‚à•L‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñù)‚Å¢(t)‚Å¢d‚Å¢t)‚Å¢(1-e-T1Œµ)<1. Then we apply the Banach fixed point theorem to find a unique uŒµ‚ààùíû‚Å¢([0,T1];L1‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv)) solving the Cauchy problem (3.2). By (3.7), uŒµ‚ààL‚àû‚Å¢([0,T];L‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv)), so uŒµ(T1)‚ààL1(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv))‚à©L‚àû(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv). We then repeat the argument above to extend our solution to the time interval [T1,2‚Å¢T1]. Continuing, after finitely many steps we construct a solution existing on the interval (0,T) for any T>0. From this, we demonstrate that there exists a unique uŒµ‚ààùíû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L1‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv))‚à©Ll‚Å¢o‚Å¢c‚àû‚Å¢([0,‚àû);L‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv)) solving the Cauchy problem (3.2). ‚àô Assertion 2: (Comparison principle). For any œÅ0,œÅ0~‚ààL‚àû‚Å¢(‚Ñùd)‚à©L1‚Å¢(‚Ñùd), the allied solutions uŒµ and u~Œµ of (3.2) satisfy

(norm@((u _ varepsilon * t - (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon * t) ^ +)) _ (L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)

exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * s * d * s)) * (norm@((chi _ rho _ 0 - chi _ (tilde@(rho)) _ 0) ^ +)) _ (L ^ 1 * (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)

exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * s * d * s)) * (norm@((rho _ 0 - (tilde@(rho)) _ 0) ^ +)) _ (L ^ 1 * R ^ d)

(norm@(rho _ varepsilon * t - (tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * t)) _ (L ^ 1 * R ^ d) less= exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * s * d * s)) * (norm@(rho _ 0 - (tilde@(rho)) _ 0)) _ (L ^ 1 * R ^ d)

(norm@(rho _ varepsilon * t - (tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * t)) _ (L ^ 1 * R ^ d) less= exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * s * d * s)) * (norm@(rho _ 0 - (tilde@(rho)) _ 0)) _ (L ^ 1 * R ^ d)

(norm@(rho _ varepsilon * t)) _ (L ^ infinity * R ^ d) less= exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * s * d * s)) * (norm@(rho _ 0)) _ (L ^ infinity * R ^ d)

(norm@(rho _ varepsilon * t)) _ (L ^ infinity * R ^ d) less= exponential@(((integral ^ t) _ 0)@((norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A)) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * s * d * s)) * (norm@(rho _ 0)) _ (L ^ infinity * R ^ d)

para.p: Furthermore, if œÅ0‚©ΩœÅ~0, for for almost all (t,x,v)‚àà(0,‚àû)√ó‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv, and almost all (t,x)‚àà(0,‚àû)√ó‚Ñùd,

Math.text: formulae@(u _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) less= (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v), rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x) less= (tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x))
formulae@(u _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) less= (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v), rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x) less= (tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x))

para.p: (3.13) holds mutatis mutandis from (3.10) and (1.5), it is sufficient to show (3.10)-(3.12). Since the calculation for (3.11) and (3.12) is analogue of (3.10), we only show (3.10) here. Let ŒªŒµ=[uŒµ-u~Œµ]+, by a tedious approximation argument, it meets

Math.text: (partial-differential _ t)@(lambda _ varepsilon) * vector@(t, x, v) + (b * v) cdot (nabla _ x)@(lambda _ varepsilon) + A * open-interval@(t, v) * (partial-differential _ v)@(lambda _ varepsilon) = (1 / varepsilon) * (chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - u _ varepsilon - (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon

(partial-differential _ t)@(lambda _ varepsilon) * vector@(t, x, v) + (b * v) cdot (nabla _ x)@(lambda _ varepsilon) + A * open-interval@(t, v) * (partial-differential _ v)@(lambda _ varepsilon) = (1 / varepsilon) * (chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - u _ varepsilon - (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon

para.p: in (0,‚àû)√ó‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv, with the initial data

Math.text: evaluated-at@(lambda _ varepsilon, t = 0) = list@((chi _ (rho _ 0 * x) * v - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ 0 * x) * v) ^ +, [in], (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)
evaluated-at@(lambda _ varepsilon, t = 0) = list@((chi _ (rho _ 0 * x) * v - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ 0 * x) * v) ^ +, [in], (R ^ d) _ x * R _ v)

para.p: Notice that,

Math.text: (chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - u _ varepsilon - (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon = (chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x))) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon - lambda _ varepsilon

(chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - u _ varepsilon - (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon = (chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x))) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon - lambda _ varepsilon

para.p: and

Math.text: (integral _ R)@((chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v) less= (integral _ R)@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v)

para.p: Indeed, when œÅŒµ‚©ΩœÅ~Œµ, (3.17) is nature and reversely,

Math.text: (integral _ R)@((chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v) less= (integral _ R)@((chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v) * d * v) = (integral _ R)@((u _ varepsilon - (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon) * d * v) less= (integral _ R)@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v)
(integral _ R)@((chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v) * [sign] * lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v)
(integral _ R)@((chi _ (rho _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v - chi _ ((tilde@(rho)) _ varepsilon * open-interval@(t, x)) * v) * d * v)
(integral _ R)@((u _ varepsilon - (tilde@(u)) _ varepsilon) * d * v)
(integral _ R)@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v)

para.p: By (3.16),(3.17), from (3.14) it follows that

Math.text: partial-differential _ t * (integral _ R)@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v) + (integral _ R)@((b * v) cdot (nabla _ x)@(lambda _ varepsilon * d * v)) less= (integral _ R)@((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * open-interval@(t, v) * lambda _ varepsilon * d * v) less= (norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * t) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * (integral _ R)@(lambda _ varepsilon * d * v)

partial-differential _ t * (integral _ R)@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * v) + (integral _ R)@((b * v) cdot (nabla _ x)@(lambda _ varepsilon * d * v)) less= (integral _ R)@((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * open-interval@(t, v) * lambda _ varepsilon * d * v) less= (norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * t) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * (integral _ R)@(lambda _ varepsilon * d * v)

para.p: which suggests that for any œÜ‚ààùíü‚Å¢(‚Ñùd),

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * varphi * x * d * x * d * v) less= (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@((b * v) cdot (nabla _ x)@(varphi * lambda _ varepsilon * d * x * d * v)) + (norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * t) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * varphi * d * x * d * v)

(d / (d * t)) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * varphi * x * d * x * d * v) less= (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@((b * v) cdot (nabla _ x)@(varphi * lambda _ varepsilon * d * x * d * v)) + (norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * t) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * varphi * d * x * d * v)

para.p: For any k‚àà‚Ñï, we can choose œÜ such that for any 0‚©Ω|x|‚©Ωk, œÜ‚Å¢(x)=1, then by letting k tend to infinity, one deduces

Math.text: (d / (d * t)) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * x * d * v) less= (norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * t) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * x * d * v)

(d / (d * t)) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * x * d * v) less= (norm@(((partial-differential _ v)@(A) * t) ^ +)) _ (L ^ infinity * R) * (integral _ ((R ^ d) _ x * R _ v))@(lambda _ varepsilon * vector@(t, x, v) * d * x * d * v)

para.p: On account of the fact: for any Œ±1,Œ±2‚àà‚Ñù,

(iii) (1.7) can be solvable by the stochastic characteristic method for general forcing A=A‚Å¢(t,x,œÅ) and flux B=B‚Å¢(t,x,œÅ), when b‚Å¢(t,x,v)=‚àÇv‚Å°B‚Å¢(t,x,v) and A are Lipschitz. But in Theorem 3.1, this method is not adapted, for one may establish the fundamental existence results on weak solutions for a large scale on b and A. Then the renormalization technique applies, one may obtain the existence of stochastic weak solutions for (1.7) on weaker assumptions on b and A, especially for the case of non-Lipschitz vector fields (for example one can see [11] and [12] for the linear stochastic transport equation). And now if the weak solution is unique, it can be given by: for any œï‚ààùíü‚Å¢(‚Ñùxd√ó‚Ñùv),

(iv) All above restrictions on B and A seem to be rigid, but there are many models in statistic physics and fluid mechanics, satisfying all the hypotheses, we intend to illustrate it by displaying a typical example now.

This example is concerned with the Buckley-Leverett equation (see [13]), which provides a simple model for the rectilinear flow of immiscible fluids (phases) through a porous medium. To be simple, nevertheless, to capture some of the qualitative features, here we consider the case of two-phase flows (such as oil and water) in one space dimension. In this issue, the Buckley-Leverett equation, with an external force, and a stochastic perturbation reads
